text: I did not think that I would be back here
blasting ass so quickly after our last video,
but something happened yesterday that was so disturbing, and so shocking,
that I truly had to come back and make another video about it.
Now let me start by saying that lately
it seems like companies, huge companies, are leaking peoples data
all over the place.
I mean, I looked at this website here
InformationIsBeautiful.net
and visualized the worlds biggest data breaches.
Just take a look at this here.
MySpace: A hundred and sixty-four million.
Ebay: One hundred and forty-five million
JP Morgan and Chase - They're supposed to be a banking institution.
How do they not have better security?
Seventy-six million.
Home Depot.
Target.
Ubisoft.
Tumblr.
Voter Database!
A hundred and ninety-one million.
Literally. I feel like peoples social security number at this point
is just a matter of public knowledge
and if that's not terrible and scary enough
it seems that companies now are just outright
giving your information away to anybody that asks for it.
So yesterday, umm,
we were targeted by one of these hackers that's been going around
taking control of very popular people's pages.
LeafyIsHere got hacked.
Boogie got hacked recently.
LinusTechTips got hacked.
And you think to yourself "How the fuck do people get in a YouTube account?!
They have two-step verification and a bunch of security.
How is it possible?"
Well, we know. We figured it out because they tried it on us
and it is horrifying!
So these hackers were able to acquire my SIM card
from T-Mobile itself. From our carrier.
They called and impersonated a T-Mobile employee
and, you know, T-Mobile being the gracious host that they are
wanted to provide a great service to them
by giving them our fucking SIM card!
These guys had the card
in their phone
they had access to my text messages,
my contacts - everything in my fucking phone
we were five minutes away from them having
access to our YouTube channel
and basically completely fucking us.
And the only reason we were able to stop it
is because I had talked to one of my friends who was
hacked by them recently and I knew how
the attack was taking place.
That, you know, their technique now is that they get
your SIM card from your phone company
and that's how they do it
These fucking guys even called my mom yesterday morning at six-thirty
impersonating T-Mobile employees.
So they're definitely hitting this thing on all sides just looking for the weak points
and T-Mobile security and, hell, there's a lot of weak points
so yesterday morning somebody from T-Mobile calls me and he says "hey, just wanna let you know-"
"-that there's been somebody who's been requesting your information a lot-"
"-he claims that he works with T-Mobile and that he's in there with the store with you-"
"-now, a lot of people have - whenever we deny him the information, he just hangs up-"
"-so, we want to call and set up some extra securities, to secure your account."
And his suggestion was that we set up a pass code, so we set up the pass code
He makes a note in the system saying, you know...
don't give out their SIM card or that they're under threat, you know, from a security breach
and, uh
We're really relieved, we're like "man, dude, that was a close call."
Me and Hila were just about to go about our day
And about thirty minutes after that my cellphone, the service drops. Completely.
It just goes completely. Like the 4G just disappears.
And I try to make a call, surely, it's like... no activity.
And immediately I'm like "they've got the SIM, they've got the SIM, I'm shut off, I'm being hacked right fucking now."
So I'm panicking. I call up T-Mobile
I get them on the phone and I'm like "Yo! I talked to somebody thirty minutes ago-"
"-they said that somebody that somebody was trying to hack me and get my SIM card-"
"-I think they got it because my service got shut off-"
(frantic) "-my SIM card's hacked, I'm being attacked, I'm a popular YouTuber, this is very urgent!"
[relaxing music plays] She goes (calm voice) "okay, definitely can take look into that for you-"
"-just wanna let you know that your bill is due in ten days and if you wanna go ahead and try our new T-Mobile app-"
"-you can pay it that way, it's a lot more convenient, and I think you're gonna enjoy it a lot, so-"
"-are you interested in downloading our new app?"
Did you not listen?! This is urgent!
Like the lady has no urgency at all. She's pitching her new fucking app.
(corporate music) She just goes (calm) "well it does appear that somebody did call earlier this morning and, uh-"
"-we did give them your SIM card because they said they work with T-Mobile."
And I'm like "oh, that's..."
"... yeah, that sounds reasonable, um..."
"... so, if you wanna go ahead, I mean, if you're interested, I don't wanna tell you how to do your job-"
"-but if you wanna go ahead and activate my SIM card and maybe just fucking blast their's into outer space-"
-"but first, can you tell me a little more about your special promotions?"
So, basically, she deactivates their SIM, reactivates our SIM
and, for now, I'm relieved 'cause at least I got my phone back but I'm completely panicking.
It's like "how the fuck did this happen, lady?! Can you explain how did this happen?"
[more relaxing music] "Well, it appears that after you set up your passcode with the rep that called you this morning-"
"-they were able to login to your account using the pass code that you set up..."
"-I that I've been helpful today. Have I resolved your issue?"
[bangs desk]
(in a high-pitched voice) WHAAT?!
What kind of extra security is that?!
Like, are you fucking kidding me?
So they called to set up an extra security measure to prevent me from getting hacked
and it turns out their extra security measure made me more vulnerable
because somehow, it seems that generating that pass code was part of their plan to get into my account
because before they couldn't do it and thirty almost directly after we set up the pass code
they were able to get in my account.
So it turns out you need either my social security number *or* the pass code to get in
You don't need both.
And, apparently, it's a lot easier to get the pass code impersonating a T-Mobile agent
than it is to get straight access to my SIM card
There's a fundamental failure here at T-Mobile to protect their customer's identity
And this isn't just a fluke, it's happened to SO many people!
[creepy music in background] An even more terrifying case of a utility company giving up their client's information and endangering them
came from this New York Times article entitled "The Serial Swatter"
HayliNic is a small Twitch streamer with a really creepy obsessive fan
When he wanted to obtain her address, he called up cable company COX communications
He called up COX telling them that he worked there and without batting an eye
they gave him her home address
What happened soon after was a SWAT team showed up at her door with guns drawn.
She was lucky not to be hurt or killed.
This is one story of many that has happened
And it's going to keep happening, and that's what's so scary
and that's why I wanted to make this video
to let YouTubers and other people, the social presence, know that this is how the hackers will attack you.
They are gonna get your SIM card. From your Communications company
and they are gonna get your 2-step verification from your SIM card.
This is how it's happening.
So what can you do to protect it? Call your phone company right now.
Don't wait. Call them and tell them.
"Don't give my SIM to any one but me no matter what."
Tell them to put an extra security note on your account and don't ever give up your SIM.
But this is the scary thing
is that even though we've done all that, I still feel like I'm just as vulnerable as I was
because I'm relying on someone at T-Mobile to read the notes and tell the hacker
"Oh, sorry, I'm not gonna give you this person's SIM card to a total stranger."
We got lucky because we understood how the attack happened.
I mean it is a terrifying feeling knowing that someone malicious out there has your SIM card in their phone,
they have access to your contacts, your e-mails,
your text messages. I don't know, they had everything they needed to get into my Gmail account.
It's horrifying!
It's like a digital rape.
So we're considering to sue T-Mobile because the only language these companies understand
is money - Money talks,
and if they don't lose money, then they have no reason to change their policy at all.
So I wanna light a fire under their ass.
And we're really thinking about suing them because the policy is not gonna change any other way.
The funniest thing for me is that you think about these hackers as like some seriously elite, like skilled people
it seems like magic. You have no idea how they're doing it - but when you find out
it's like, it's just ugly, it's disappointing, there's no magic there.
It's literally just your fucking own phone company giving you up.
That's the hack!
Your own phone company giving you up!
[exciting, fast-paced action music plays]
[frantic typing can be heard]
[loud thunder sound]

[music stops]
[T-Mobile jingle]
[Pre-recorded voice] "T-Mobile"
Hi, um, I work for T-Mobile
and I'm here with, uh, Felix, also known as PewDiePie, a popular YouTuber.

[Pre-recorded voice] "Sorry, I still didn't hear you"
Uhh...
"To continue..."
I'm here with PewDiePie, uh, we were here trying to get a SIM card
he was having trouble with his phone
could you please send me the SIM card for PewDiePie, please?

[thunder rolls] [PewDiePie screams]
Oh! Oh! Oh no! Oh!
[H3H3 theme song plays as outro music]
